reasoning: The critique targets the essay’s main optimistic pathway in section 3 (partial AM-convergence plus trade/compromise). If extortion reliably dominates, that would substantially reduce the essay’s optimism about reaching mostly-great futures via bargaining, so centrality is moderate. However, the position already foregrounds threats as a major obstacle (sec. 3.3–3.4), explicitly noting that even small fractions of executed threats can eat most value and that threats could make outcomes worse than extinction. So the critique mostly reiterates a point the essay already makes, and doesn’t engage the essay’s nuances (e.g., conditions where threats are prevented, dependence on axiologies, institutional possibilities), limiting strength. Several claims are overstated or insufficiently supported (e.g., “infinitely cheaper,” near-inevitable ‘basilisk’ equilibrium, altruists driven to zero resources), though the general direction (threats can swamp trade, destruction can be cheaper than creation, extortion incentives exist) is plausible, yielding middling correctness. The critique is clear, focused, and contains little fluff.
title: Moral trade incentivizes extortion strategies that bleed altruistic agents dry
